linkTarget.anchoringText: Evolution of approaches to the development of oil rims is presented, based on the results of full-scale development of large oil and gas fields of East Siberia (Verkhnechonskoye, Srednebotuobinskoye, and Yaraktinskoye) put into production, in which a significant share of oil reserves (29% to 69%) is concentrated in the areas having a gas cap on top (figure 1).

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Map with investigated fields in Eastern Siberia

formatted-caption.caption-text: Map with investigated fields in Eastern Siberia

linkTarget.anchoringText: Reservoir of Vc horizon is characterized by non-uniform structure. Net-to-gross ratio (NTG) varies over a wide range of 0.1 to 0.8, with an average value of 0.44 (stratification factor is equal to 6.9). At the same time, the Vc formation can be described as a highly productive reservoir: on average, the productivity index (PI) of exploration wells is equal to 2.1 m3/day /atm, and that of horizontal wells (HW) is equal to 5.9 m3/ day /atm (figure 1.1), due to relatively high permeability of 170 mD (the average for the major blocks varies within 109 mD to 441 mD).

image-wrap.label: Figure 1.1
image-wrap.caption: Productivity index of exploration and horizontal wells

formatted-caption.caption-text: Productivity index of exploration and horizontal wells

linkTarget.anchoringText: Based on the core data and field data, halite crystals (NaCl) were detected in the pore space [7]. It is assumed that salt migration occurred along faults, which is indirectly proved by the increase in the proportion of salts in the pores in the direction towards the tectonic faults, in some cases up to complete salinization of the reservoir (figure 1.2).

image-wrap.label: Figure 1.2
image-wrap.caption: Thin section of Vc sandstone with salt crystals (2–illite, 5-quartz, 7-halite)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Thin section of Vc sandstone with salt crystals (2–illite, 5-quartz, 7-halite)

linkTarget.anchoringText: In particular, at the Verkhnechonskoye field, as part of the 1998 Development Plan, for GOZ zones it was planned to drill horizontal wells with the length of the horizontal sections of 600 m, arranged in 9-point waterflood pattern where in the middle of a cell there were located vertical injection wells, and in the rows containing injection wells between them there were planned slant production wells (figure 1.3) [10].

image-wrap.label: Figure 1.3
image-wrap.caption: Evolution of solutions on development of the GOZ zones of the Verkhnechonskoye field 1998 year 1: 3 (inj /prod), 36 he/well Producers are horizontal/slant; Injectors are slant; Lengths are 600 m 2009 year 1: 2 (inj /prod), 56 he/well Producers are horizontal/slant; Injectors are slant; Lengths are 500 m 2016 year 1: 2 (inj /prod), 40 he/well Producers are horizontal/slant; Injectors are slant; Lengths are 900 m Predicted GORs and oil flow rates over a period of 30 years

formatted-caption.caption-text: Evolution of solutions on development of the GOZ zones of the Verkhnechonskoye field 1998 year 1: 3 (inj /prod), 36 he/well Producers are horizontal/slant; Injectors are slant; Lengths are 600 m 2009 year 1: 2 (inj /prod), 56 he/well Producers are horizontal/slant; Injectors are slant; Lengths are 500 m 2016 year 1: 2 (inj /prod), 40 he/well Producers are horizontal/slant; Injectors are slant; Lengths are 900 m Predicted GORs and oil flow rates over a period of 30 years

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: 1998 year 1: 3 (inj /prod), 36 he/well Producers are horizontal/slant; Injectors are slant; Lengths are 600 m
2009 year 1: 2 (inj /prod), 56 he/well Producers are horizontal/slant; Injectors are slant; Lengths are 500 m
2016 year 1: 2 (inj /prod), 40 he/well Producers are horizontal/slant; Injectors are slant; Lengths are 900 m
Predicted GORs and oil flow rates over a period of 30 years

linkTarget.anchoringText: As the experience was acquired in producing and operating wells in the areas where the OZ zones adjoined the GOZ zones, and in the marginal areas of the GOZ zones, decisions were made to install perforated liners at 3 to 5 meters below the oil and gas contact (GOC), and to limit the drawdown to 20 atm within the approved development plan. If necessary, drawdown is limited to less than 20 atm in order to reduce production of breakthrough gas from the gas cap (figure 1.4).

linkTarget.anchoringText: The problem is in the growth of GOR due to the breakthrough of gas from the gas cap, as there is an uncertainty regarding continuity of clay interlayers within the development area, those identified by the logging data, and on the basis of which the trajectories of the horizontal wells were chosen; this is demonstrated on the example of two wells drilled in 2015 in the GOZ zone as a pilot project (PP) (figure 1.9). In the future, the geometry of non-reservoirs in the geological and simulation model will be corrected on the basis of actual well operation data.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1.9
image-wrap.caption: Comparison of characteristics of displacement for the zones of GOZ

linkTarget.anchoringText: Two equivalent geological models based on the poroperm properties (Figure A.4) have significant differences from the viewpoint of the effectiveness of the development of the oil rim (figure 1.10), again because of the continuity of the clay intervals of the Vc2 formation. Thus, the maximum level of oil production in the case of continuous clay intervals (15 km) is 44% higher (for 15 km it is 331 thousand tons, for 2 km it is 185 thousand tons), and the maximum GOR value is 158% lower (for 15 Km it is 442 m3/ton, for 2 km it is 1140 m3/ton).

image-wrap.label: Figure 1.10
image-wrap.caption: Comparison of flow rates and GORs with different ranges of variograms for the GOZ zones

formatted-caption.caption-text: Comparison of flow rates and GORs with different ranges of variograms for the GOZ zones

image-wrap.caption: Estimate of technological efficiency of the optimized approach development of waterflood system for the GOZ zones (15 km)

linkTarget.anchoringText: There are four major tectonic blocks: the Western, Northern, Central and Eastern. The bulk of the hydrocarbon reserves of the deposit is concentrated within the Central Block. The gas-oil and water-oil contacts (tilted [14]) cause different fluid zones - gas-water and water-oil zones (figure 2.1). In view of the field isolation by tectonic faults, the activity of the aquifer zone is practically not manifested.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2.1
image-wrap.caption: The result of logging data interpretation in well 3278Pl

formatted-caption.caption-text: The result of logging data interpretation in well 3278Pl

linkTarget.anchoringText: For the Bt target, the solution for the location of the development system, its type, HW well lengths (Table 2.1,Figure 2.2 - indicators without changing the distance between the wells in a type plot), the organization of water flooding (WF), the placement of the effective part of the holes in the section and the recoveries (drawdown in a well depending on a zone) was developed in 2014-2015 with the use of numerical simulation based on the geological and commercial information available at that time [1].

image-wrap.label: Figure 2.2
image-wrap.caption: Determination of the optimal Hz length for complex parameter (Oil RF, NPV) for the G/O/W zone

formatted-caption.caption-text: Determination of the optimal Hz length for complex parameter (Oil RF, NPV) for the G/O/W zone

linkTarget.anchoringText: Top-level solutions are: the use of HW wells; with a two-stage WF system and water as a displacement agent - for the W/O zone; with the return of produced associated petroleum gas (APG) (dissolved oil and gas of the gas cap breaking through the bottomholes of production oil wells) from the target to the gas injection wells located in the dome part of the gas cap. In the W/O zone, the WF system is formed in two stages; I - formation of a 9-spot system; II - conversion of the second-stage wells to injection, formation of a line-drive system. The accepted design well patterns by zone are shown in Figure 2.3.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2.3
image-wrap.caption: Planned well systems by zone: A) - O/W zone, B) - G/O/W zone

formatted-caption.caption-text: Planned well systems by zone: A) - O/W zone, B) - G/O/W zone

linkTarget.anchoringText: In the O/W zone - at the maximum distance from water-saturated intervals (2-3 meters from the top). Water wells have a descending trajectory (figure 2.4).

image-wrap.label: Figure 2.4
image-wrap.caption: Locations of planned wells by zone and within a cross-section

formatted-caption.caption-text: Locations of planned wells by zone and within a cross-section

linkTarget.anchoringText: The production potential study began with a pilot project generated in 1983. It was intended to place directional wells with 600 meter spacing. The area covered both the G/O/W zone and the O/W zone (86% and 14%, respectively). Two-stage operation was planned: initially on depletion, followed by WF (figure 2.5A). The estimated RF for the site is 0.18.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2.5
image-wrap.caption: Evolution of project decisions for gas-oil zones

formatted-caption.caption-text: Evolution of project decisions for gas-oil zones

linkTarget.anchoringText: In the period from 2010 (decision on 500-m HW length) until 2014 (HW length of 1,250 meters), wells with an average length of 750 meters were drilled in the field. Figure 2.6 presents the planned oil recovery figures for the G/O/W zone, estimated in various FDPs, taking into account a tighter well pattern, as well as the average PI values actually achieved (the actual performance of 1250-meter HW wells is not enough so far since the wells are still being drilled and put into production).

image-wrap.label: Figure 2.6
image-wrap.caption: Comparison of expected oil RF for the G/O/W zone and actual PI

formatted-caption.caption-text: Comparison of expected oil RF for the G/O/W zone and actual PI

linkTarget.anchoringText: At the moment, it is too early to speak about the final oil recovery, the target is at its initial stage of development, but the actual data confirm the feasibility of the decision to increase the Hz length, as the PI of wells increases, which is confirmed by flow tests and logging in the wells. Another positive factor to support the increasing length of the wells is longer working hours of the wells until gas breaks through to the HW well bottomholes (figure 2.7).

image-wrap.label: Figure 2.7
image-wrap.caption: Comparison of the GOR profile by the recoveries from wells of different lengths located in thicker and thinner net pay layers (estimated and actual indicators)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Comparison of the GOR profile by the recoveries from wells of different lengths located in thicker and thinner net pay layers (estimated and actual indicators)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Yaraktinskoe Field is attributed to gentle monocline. Separate blocks with different fluid contacts are sealed with lithology change or non-conductive faults. Average structure dip is 2.9 m per 1000 m, min=0.03/1000 m, max = 11/1000 m, standard deviation = 2.2 m. Structural uncertainty may lead to +/- 3000 m change in gas cap edge in planar view. Pore volume of gas to oil relation is 0.8:1, gas and oil are in contact within 37% of field area (figure 3.1).

image-wrap.label: Figure 3.1
image-wrap.caption: Fluid zones, reservoir top map.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Fluid zones, reservoir top map.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Permeability is strongly variable vertically and horizontally. According to core data arithmetic average is 93 mD, max = 1698 mD, standard deviation = 232 mD; well test data indicate arithmetic average having 204 mD, max = 5000 mD, standard deviation = 508 mD. Histogram for both data sets is similar and bimodal (figure 3.2 a). Two modes in core data illustrates the presence of two petrotypes of different flow capacity. Well test data is bimodal due to local high permeability zones within low permeability background (figure 3.2 b).

image-wrap.label: Figure 3.2a
image-wrap.caption: Permeability histogram

formatted-caption.caption-text: Permeability histogram

linkTarget.anchoringText: Permeability is strongly variable vertically and horizontally. According to core data arithmetic average is 93 mD, max = 1698 mD, standard deviation = 232 mD; well test data indicate arithmetic average having 204 mD, max = 5000 mD, standard deviation = 508 mD. Histogram for both data sets is similar and bimodal (figure 3.2 a). Two modes in core data illustrates the presence of two petrotypes of different flow capacity. Well test data is bimodal due to local high permeability zones within low permeability background (figure 3.2 b).

image-wrap.label: Figure 3.2b

formatted-caption.caption-text: Permeability field

linkTarget.anchoringText: Breaks between oil and gas zones are not uniform in thickness and extent as a result of “homogeneously heterogeneous” nature of the formation (figure 3.3).

linkTarget.anchoringText: As a first step, the various combinations of distances between rows of wells and horizontal well lengths were calculated with the NPV best results for 1150 m well spacing option, (figure 3.5).

image-wrap.label: Figure 3.5
image-wrap.caption: The results of preliminary calculations.

formatted-caption.caption-text: The results of preliminary calculations.

linkTarget.anchoringText: As a second step, detailed wells arrangement was performed to fit the best variant with existing drilled zones. (figure 3.6). Increased values of NPV correspond to variants with horizontal wells length 600 m and 1000 m (+26.87% and +36.84%) relative to the base case. Changes in cumulative oil production are relatively small (-1.28% и +1.78%) with significant number of wells reduction (-25.3%). The average parameters for every option are presented on Figure 3.7. Finally, the variant with 600 m wellbore length was accepted based on technical constraints (with the possibility of extension up to 1000 m if meeting the criteria of implementation).

image-wrap.label: Figure 3.6a
image-wrap.caption: Base option

formatted-caption.caption-text: Base option

Changes in cumulative oil production are relatively small (-1.28% и +1.78%) with significant number of wells reduction (-25.3%). The average parameters for every option are presented on Figure 3.7. Increased values of NPV correspond to variants with horizontal wells length 600 m and 1000 m (+26.87% and +36.84%) relative to the base case. Changes in cumulative oil production are relatively small (-1.28% и +1.78%) with significant number of wells reduction (-25.3%). The average parameters for every option are presented on Figure 3.7. linkTarget.anchoringText: According to the pilot test in oil bearing zone the optimal injection/production wells ratio was defined as 1/3, which allows providing sufficient voidage replacement (no less than 120%). Taking into account the pilot test results and increased reservoir volume production (as result of gas breakthrough) along with significant lateral heterogeneity the flexible flood pattern was proposed. Approach implies the 9-spot system application with additional selective well conversion to injection according to 5-spot pattern (in relation to drilling results and ability of voidage replacement ensuring). (figure 3.8).

image-wrap.label: Figure 3.8
image-wrap.caption: Water flooding elements

formatted-caption.caption-text: Water flooding elements

linkTarget.anchoringText: On June 1, 2017 there is no a sufficient statistics for horizontal wells performance within gas cap zone (less than 15 wells with average working period 0.5 year). Nevertheless there is possibility to identify two characteristic types of behavior for GOR in time: 1 - quick and sharp gas breakthrough (red colour), 2 - smooth growth (blue colour). (figure 3.9).

image-wrap.label: Figure 3.9
image-wrap.caption: GOR behavior in time for horizontal wells in gas cap zones

formatted-caption.caption-text: GOR behavior in time for horizontal wells in gas cap zones

linkTarget.anchoringText: On June 1, 2017 there is no a sufficient statistics for horizontal wells performance within gas cap zone (less than 15 wells with average working period 0.5 year). Nevertheless there is possibility to identify two characteristic types of behavior for GOR in time: 1 - quick and sharp gas breakthrough (red colour), 2 - smooth growth (blue colour). (figure 3.9).

image-wrap.label: Figure 3.9
image-wrap.caption: Wells grouping according to GOR behavior

formatted-caption.caption-text: Wells grouping according to GOR behavior

linkTarget.anchoringText: For Yaraktinskoe Filed an average time delay in injection system start is 1.5 year. Therefore the further stage of optimization program was to determine the production wells regimes during depletion period. To solve the problem the synthetic simulation model (“layer-cake” type) was constructed. (figure 3.10). Lithology and porosity distribution was performed in reliance on vertical proportion curves from wellbores in oil rims zones. Permeability and saturation were calculated in agreement to core correlations. Dimension and parameters of the model presented in Table A.1.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3.10
image-wrap.caption: Synthetic simulation model

formatted-caption.caption-text: Synthetic simulation model

linkTarget.anchoringText: Wells’ performance statistics was used for history matching. Optimistic and pessimistic models were created with different gas breakthrough time. Based on pessimistic case the 6 different models were obtained which correspond to 6 various PI values. Optimal operating parameters were defined for different lifting methods with technical constraints (GORmax =1000 [sm3]/[sm3] for pump and THP=20 [atm] for free flow production). (figure 3.11). According to simulation and nodal analysis the free flow production can provide the largest drawdown and oil production total during 1.5 year time period with recommended tubing size 114 mm (60 mm for PI<=1.5 [sm3]/[day]/[atm]).

image-wrap.label: Figure 3.11
image-wrap.caption: Cumulative oil production and average drawdown values for optimal operating regimes

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cumulative oil production and average drawdown values for optimal operating regimes

linkTarget.anchoringText: AICD [28] is proposed as one of the methods to control early breakthrough of gas within the pilot projects conducted before the end of 2017. The assumptions to apply the AICD is the positive effect demonstrated by the simulation for the overwhelming part of planned wells with primary injection (average incremental oil production is 17%) (figure 3.12, Figure A.9).

image-wrap.label: Figure 3.12
image-wrap.caption: AICD installation in planned Well 10 (primary completion)

formatted-caption.caption-text: AICD installation in planned Well 10 (primary completion)

linkTarget.anchoringText: The Verkhnechonskoye field (VCNG) is a large field according to reserves classification, hydrocarbon productivity is associated with the Verkhnechonskiy horizon of the Nepskaya suite (a depth of 1600 m), the Preobrazhenskiy horizon (formation of Pr) of the Katangskiy suite (a depth of 1500 m), the Ust-Kutskiy horizon (formation of Uk) of the Teterskaya suite (a depth of 1300 m), and the Osinskiy horizon (formation Os) of the Usolskaya suite (a depth of 1200 m) (figure A.1) [4].

image-wrap.label: Figure A.1
image-wrap.caption: Lithological stratigraphic scheme of the Verkhnechonskoye field

formatted-caption.caption-text: Lithological stratigraphic scheme of the Verkhnechonskoye field

linkTarget.anchoringText: In the lower part of the formation there are confidently traced facies of alluvial fans. Formation of alluvial fans took place in conditions of active bringing in of coarse-grained material, gravelstone, from the continent into the edge zone of the sedimentation basin, which is found at the bottom of Vc1 and Vc2 layers. Above the section lies the main productive pack of Vc reservoir formed by migratory channel facies of temporary paleostreams that accumulated in the active fluvial hydrodynamics (figure A.2) [5].

image-wrap.label: Figure A.2
image-wrap.caption: Schematic facial cross-plot of Vc the reservoir of wells 505-648-1436 (direction: continent → basin)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Schematic facial cross-plot of Vc the reservoir of wells 505-648-1436 (direction: continent → basin)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Important geological features of the Vc formation are the presence of block tectonics and the presence of salts in the pore space [6]. Within the field, nine main tectonic blocks are distinguished. Besides, the Usolsky graben of 0.5-0.9 km width is distinguished with confidence, based on seismic data and productivity confirmed by drilling. Tectonic faults cause different levels of waterand gas-oil contacts in blocks, dividing them into gas-oil and pure oil zones (Figure A.3). Due to the numerous tectonic faults, aquifer beyond the outlying contour is almost absent.

image-wrap.label: Figure A.3
image-wrap.caption: Blocks and saturation areas of the Vc reservoir

formatted-caption.caption-text: Blocks and saturation areas of the Vc reservoir

linkTarget.anchoringText: Therefore, to assess the risks of gas breakthrough, the influence of the value of the range of a sandstone/clay variogram on the dynamics of flow rates and ratios was evaluated. The current geological model with a range of 15 km and a riskreduced model with a range of 2 km were considered (the ranges of variograms for the layers of Vc1 and Vc2 could not be selected because of high reservoir variability) with the subsequent calculation of the predicted parameters in a simulation model (SM) (Figure A.4).

image-wrap.label: Figure A.4
image-wrap.caption: Comparison of the inhomogeneity of a cross-section of the Vc formation when simulated with different ranges of variograms of nonreservoirs

formatted-caption.caption-text: Comparison of the inhomogeneity of a cross-section of the Vc formation when simulated with different ranges of variograms of nonreservoirs

linkTarget.anchoringText: The main purpose of creating geological models with different variogram ranges and subsequent calculations based on them was to show the change in the waterflood system development depending of the continuity of clay intervals (Figure A.5). The types of wells, production or injection, vary depending on the continuity of the Vc2 formation due to the dominance of gas filtration in the horizontal or vertical direction, which is clearly shown in Figure A.6. By the way, reservoir pressure dynamics is not lower than 120 atm (initial pressure - 155 atm) in depletion cases (due to abandonment of the wells).

image-wrap.label: Figure A.5
image-wrap.caption: Comparison of changes in the design assignment of wells (production or injection) at different continuity of clay intervals

formatted-caption.caption-text: Comparison of changes in the design assignment of wells (production or injection) at different continuity of clay intervals

linkTarget.anchoringText: The main purpose of creating geological models with different variogram ranges and subsequent calculations based on them was to show the change in the waterflood system development depending of the continuity of clay intervals (Figure A.5). The types of wells, production or injection, vary depending on the continuity of the Vc2 formation due to the dominance of gas filtration in the horizontal or vertical direction, which is clearly shown in Figure A.6. By the way, reservoir pressure dynamics is not lower than 120 atm (initial pressure - 155 atm) in depletion cases (due to abandonment of the wells).

image-wrap.label: Figure A.6
image-wrap.caption: Comparison of oil extraction efficiency and reservoir pressure of the Vc formation at different continuity of clay

formatted-caption.caption-text: Comparison of oil extraction efficiency and reservoir pressure of the Vc formation at different continuity of clay

linkTarget.anchoringText: Srednebotuobinskoye Field (SBB) belongs to large-reserves deposits, with the productivity confined to Botuobinsky Horizon of the Lower Bucksky Sub-series (the depth of occurrence of productive deposits is 1900 m) and Osinsky Horizon of the Bilirsky Series of the Lower Cambrian (depth of 1540 m). The field cross-section also includes the following horizons which can be traced regionally: Khamakinsky; Arylakhsky; Talakhsky; Ulakhansky horizons of Kursovsky Series confined to a different part of the crosssection. These horizons are characterized by varying degrees of knowledge, mainly poor, and at the moment have not been booked in the state balance sheet (Figure A.7) [13].

image-wrap.label: Figure A.7
image-wrap.caption: Lithologic-stratigraphic scheme of the Srednebotuobinskoye field

formatted-caption.caption-text: Lithologic-stratigraphic scheme of the Srednebotuobinskoye field

linkTarget.anchoringText: A barlike body, with the axial part of a northeasterly strike, was formed under conditions of a slow transgression of the sea basin. To the northwest of the field, there was an extensive lower shore zone, stretching along a very gently sloping coast. The bar-like body was probably formed by along-coast tidal currents (northeasterly). In the southeast direction, the sandstone thickness of the Botuobinsky horizon is reduced within the prefrontal shore zone, up to complete absence in the slope shelf zone (Figure A.8).

image-wrap.label: Figure A.8
image-wrap.caption: Scheme of depositional environment of the productive part of the Bt reservoir

formatted-caption.caption-text: Scheme of depositional environment of the productive part of the Bt reservoir

linkTarget.anchoringText: AICD [28] is proposed as one of the methods to control early breakthrough of gas within the pilot projects conducted before the end of 2017. The assumptions to apply the AICD is the positive effect demonstrated by the simulation for the overwhelming part of planned wells with primary injection (average incremental oil production is 17%) (figure 3.12, Figure A.9).

image-wrap.label: Picture A.9
image-wrap.caption: AICD performance for well 50 (primary completion)

formatted-caption.caption-text: AICD performance for well 50 (primary completion)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Within the pilot project, it is also planned to install AICD in two operating production wells. This is supported by the positive effect in reducing the GOR and incremental oil produced by selected candidates (Figure A.10), as well as the adopted type of completion applying casing packers that break the wellbore into parts, the number of which varies depending on the geological conditions (Figure A.11).

image-wrap.label: Figure A.10
image-wrap.caption: Well performance with and without AICD 218 (secondary complition)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Well performance with and without AICD 218 (secondary complition)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Within the pilot project, it is also planned to install AICD in two operating production wells. This is supported by the positive effect in reducing the GOR and incremental oil produced by selected candidates (Figure A.10), as well as the adopted type of completion applying casing packers that break the wellbore into parts, the number of which varies depending on the geological conditions (Figure A.11).

image-wrap.caption: Base completion for Yaraktinskoe Field wells
